text: - Hello, everyone, welcome to this session

around real life Microsoft SQL
Server modernization stories.
My name is Sriwantha Attanayake.

I'm a Senior Partner
Solution Architect at Amazon,
focusing around Microsoft technologies.
In this session, I like to highlight

one of our database
modernization partner, 1CloudHub,
who has recently done an amazing database

modernization project,
where they have migrated
a large production Microsoft SQL Server

to Amazon Aurora
PostgreSQL using Babelfish.

They are here to walk you
through all the corner points
and the process they went through
when they did this modernization project,

and it's my pleasure to
introduce Ramakrishna Phani,

Global Head of Cloud
Practices at 1CloudHub.
Over to you, Phani.
- Thank you, Sri, and hello everyone.
Thanks for joining us this session.

Today, we'll show you how to
plan your modernization path

so that you can work from
traditional commercial options

and use modern database
platforms like RDS on Aurora.

And you'll save tens
and thousands of dollars

in this process, avoiding
software assurance costs
and licensing costs.

We'll walk you through
the modernization process

with a real world example of
a SQL Server to PostgreSQL
migration using Babelfish.
This is a first of its kind implementation

in the world for Babelfish
on PostgreSQL Aurora.

The customer is one of the
largest container shipping
businesses in the world.
Present on every continent and operating
in over 160 countries worldwide.
This multi-billion dollar enterprise

had recently acquired a large
shipping company in Singapore.
As part of this acquisition,
came a massive IT consolidation challenge,
AWS was of course, the platform of choice.
The consolidation effort required
moving more than 200 applications,
along with their databases,

a third of which, were
of course, SQL Server.

Now, the customer did a few
lift-and-shift migrations to AWS

and quickly realized that
the software assurance cost

of SQL Server made the entire
project cost prohibitive.
So they had to find alternatives.

They knew that they had to go
for open source alternatives,
but they did not have enough capacity
to take up the modernization challenge
and the consolidation at the same time.

This coupled with the fact
that many of the applications
lacked technical documentation.

Even a feasibility study
was difficult to conduct.
So they were looking at a fast,
but little or no code changes approach
to get into PostgreSQL Aurora.
With this challenge in front of us,

we began the initial
discovery and assessment
with app and DB teams to put together
a business case for the migration.
We started with the conventional approach
of using a schema conversion tool.
SCT as it says on the pin
has a report that can be run
to figure out the compatibility
of the source schema on the target schema.
And it will do the conversion

of the source and targets
schemas automatically
if fully compatible.

Now around this time, Babelfish
became generally available
in Singapore region.
We were aware of this product

and it's promise to
accelerate the migration
with little or no code changes,

and wanted to quickly evaluate
its fitment for our use case.
So we ran a Compass report

or a compatible assessment
report as it's called.
After running the report,
we sat down with the application teams

to understand their
readiness for the migration,

discussing topics like
upcoming feature updates,
application performance expectations,

a level of documentation
available for testing,

and any test automation
that was already there.

Based on these inputs and
the tool reports that we had,
we had to make a decision which way to go.
We wanted to go with the tool

that would meet our
performance constraints

and show high compatibility
with our use case.

Ultimately, as far as
things being compatible,
the promise of little to no code change

swung the decision in
the favor of Babelfish.

Now the application that
was using the database
was a .NET application built to use...
Be used by the business users

to notify port authorities
of incoming vessels.

The application unfortunately
lacked proper documentation
or performance benchmarks
and had to be a multilingual application.
Meaning had to support, not just English,
but local languages as well.

So we put together a program
plan for the customer
which would ensure safe delivery of value.

We began by revalidating
the business case,

including the run and
maintenance costs post-migration.

We worked out the tooling to
be used during the migration.

We of course, also had
to work out the tooling
to be used for the performance benchmark
and the functional testing.

We got the migration
to-be state architecture
signed off by the customer and went on

to arrange POC funding by
AWS for the migration effort.
We completed our migration planning,

the test plan, the cutover
and the failback plans.
And to begin with, did the UAT migration
to give us the production migration.
We conducted a full round of testing
once the UAT migration was completed.

And once we got all the
functionality working
on the PostgreSQL side,

we went on to do our first
benchmark of performance
with the SQL Server, and then later,
with the PostgreSQL as the target.
This way, we had a side by side comparison

to find any issues and
fix them immediately.
Once the UAT migration was complete
and the performance benchmarks done,
we took all the learnings that we got
from the UAT environment to improve
the cutover plan for production.

We, of course, also
implemented all the same fixes

to get the functionality up
and running in production,
which we then ultimately handed over
to the business users for testing.

While the users were
testing the application,

we prepared the system
for monitoring, backups,

and generally preparing
it for day two operations.
We updated the corresponding sort of
standard operating procedures

and the playbooks, provided
a knowledge transfer

back to the application and
the managed services team op
and new maintenance post go-live.
Needless to say, the application migration

went smooth and the
application has been running

in production for the past
three months without a hitch.
Now, any heterogeneous migration
is bound to have its challenges.

This is due to the varying
levels of compatibility
and performance for the same queries
on the source and target database engines.
The first issue we encountered
was a corruption of varbinary data
when using BMS for the migration.

There were PDF documents that
was stored in the database,
which had to be migrated to PostgreSQL.
And we had to find an alternative to BMS.

So we got innovative
and wrote a small app,

basically a few lines of
code that queried the PDFs

from SQL Server and inserted
them into PostgreSQL.

We also had a challenge in
migrating bulk insert queries,

but Babelfish 1.1 now
supports this functionality.
The original 1.0, which we used, didn't.

So we bypassed Babelfish
to write stored procedures

using copy command
instead to overcome this.

- [Sri] Good point that
you mentioned here, Phani.
So it's very important that the customers
use the latest version of Babelfish

because some of these
issues are already fixed
in the latest version of Babelfish.
Correct me if I'm wrong.
- [Phani] Absolutely, Sri.
And Babelfish team is continuously
updating the product.
In fact, now we are in version 1.2,
as we record this session.
So use the latest version.

A lot more functionality is
being supported as we speak.
So, now the application,
remember was a multilingual application,
meaning it had to support local languages.

So during testing, we
basically started having

garbage characters being
displayed on the front end,
wherever the local languages were used.
We traced the problem

back to an unsupported
collation on PostgreSQL side
and had to rewrite those stored procedures
with the native collation on PostgreSQL.
And finally, we had to rewrite pretty much
all the queries and stored procedures
that were using self join on PostgreSQL
to address performance issues there.
- [Sri] So some of these self join issues

may already be fixed in the
new version of Babelfish.
So make sure that you always
get the latest version of Babelfish.
- [Phani] Absolutely.
So having overcome all these challenges,

we were finally able
to deliver cost savings

of over $21,000 year-on-year
for this customer,
with this database alone.
We also saw an improvement in performance

for over 70% of the
queries post-migration.

Babelfish and BMS of course,
did a lot of the heavy lifting

which made this possible
to deliver the project
in quick time for the customer.

Now, looking back at this
experience and ever since,
there were, of course, a few things
that we could have improved on.
Firstly, it is very easy to fix it
on a like-to-like solution.

What I mean by this, is that
we need to look at the current

and future scenarios of data
that may include use cases

like search functionality,
reporting functionality,

or hierarchical data usage
and so on and so forth.
Now, RDBMS may not be the right target
for some of these use cases.
So be open to options.
Next, don't base the migration

just on the TCO or the
DB feasibility alone.

It is easy to tunnel vision
and forget the application
that is using the database.
So it is very important to consult

and bring the application team
early into the conversation.

Maybe the application is
being planned for a sunset.

Maybe the application
lacks a ORM implementation.

And if it does, then
the entire business case
would be on its head.

I said it earlier, but
heterogeneous migrations
will always have surprises.

We enjoyed a great working
relationship with this customer,
but we still had a few close calls.

Most projects will have daily
or weekly cadence calls.

Apart from this, have a channel
open with the customer teams

where you can communicate
issues and the steps
that you need to take to remediate them,

especially when things
start going sideways.
In our case, the customer team
actually came out of the way to help us,

fixing some issues and also
doing additional testing
to get the project back on track.
So very crucial to communicate

and work as a single
team, as a single unit.
And again, remember that the application
is a multilingual application.

So the multilingual challenge
that I spoke about earlier,

it came up during the final
user testing before go live.
Basically, days before go live,
there were garbage characters
showing up on this user screens.
And luckily we figured out the early fix

and got the application up and
running in a couple of days.
But we could have easily avoided this

if we had been using real
data with the local languages
for our testing early on.

Or at least, if we had
brought in the business users
earlier in the testing phase.
So use live data for your testing.

And finally, agree on
a performance benchmark
with the business users ahead of time.

This will save you a lot
of time during the testing.
- This is great, Phani.
You shed a lot of light around

how these real life
modernization projects works.
I'd like to ask few questions
around some challenges that you faced.

So you mentioned that
you faced some issues
when you tried to migrate varbinary data.

So in that approach, did
you thought of like using,
let's say, Amazon S3 bucket
and put all the files there,

and then refer to them
using some kind of an ID

in your database, or did
you directly go for storing
the data in the database itself?

- Yeah, so luckily the
database varbinary data

was not so large that we
had to take it into S3

as a buffer before bringing
it into the PostgreSQL side.

What we ended up doing was
writing a few lines of code
that would handle two types of scenarios.

One was the bulk insert
or bulk update of data,
the one time data transfer.

And the second was,
this is a learning again

from the UAT that we did, to
basically take the delta data
and bring it into PostgreSQL side

to enable us to minimize
the downtime required
for the production cutover.

So luckily, as I said, the
data set was small enough

that we, and we needed
it to be fast enough,

so we used the local host
to bring all the data
and then push it into PostgreSQL side,
not really going through S3 as a buffer.
- That's great.

The other question is
around the performance.

So in real life projects,
the way that you do testing

may be different from the
way that you do testing in a,
let's say, in a pet project.

Do you wanna shed some
light how you went about

to set the benchmark
for your production data
and how you tested your baseline

and how you compared it
to the actual results

that you got after
doing the modernization?
- Absolutely.

Now a couple of things had
to be addressed with this.

As I mentioned earlier,
this particular instance

did not have a performance
benchmark established
with the business users.

So it's very crucial to
have that page latency or,

you know, page load
time as a metric defined
and the user experience expected
defined with the business users.
So that's step one that we did.

And as will be the case
with a lot of migrations,

you will need to create a
like-to-like environment
to figure out any slow running queries
without network noise.

So what we did, was set up an
environment in the same VPC.
On one side SQL Server on RDS,

and on the other side
PostgreSQL Babelfish on Aurora
in the same VPC.
Had the application server connect

to both of these environments
and generated load
from the application server,
first pointing it to the SQL Server side,
then finally did another round of testing

to replicate the same
scenarios on PostgreSQL side,

identified the queries
that were running slower

on the PostgreSQL side to
tune them for performance.
We then finally also replicated
a real world scenario using JMeter,
where we recorded the page load times
of all the pages in the application

hitting both the SQL Server
and the PostgreSQL side.

So that's essentially how we
covered the performance testing
on this particular instance.
- Yeah. It's very interesting to see

how you have compared
the real world use cases,
rather than doing some hypothetical one.
You actually compared the page load time.
That's the user's experience

rather than the
hypothetical number, right?

So that's very interesting
to know how you did that.

So going back to like,
given the fact that you guys

are doing some amazing
database modernization,
do you wanna tell a bit of a story

about 1CloudHub and the kind
of competencies and the skills
you have in this space?
- Absolutely, Sri.

So as a company, we are
present in three markets now

and we are opening up the
UAE market this quarter.
We are now more than 252 strong

and have been recognized as
the best tech brand in 2021
by Economic Times in India.

Since its inception, we
have always been focused on
learning and certifications.

We now have over 195
certified cloud architects,
devops engineers, cloud engineers,
and other specialties on our team.

We achieved an advanced
tier partnership with AWS

in a record time of six
months since its inception,
since the company inception.
We have of course, continued this trend

and went on to participate
in various service delivery
and competency programs with AWS,
like the well-architected program,

and of course the database
migration delivery program.
- That's amazing how you have built
your AWS practice over time.

So let's say a customer
wants to engage you

and they are not sure
about their application.

They want to do some
kind of an assessment.
What's the engagement look like

in this kind of a database
modernization project?

Do you wanna shed some light
around your engagement model
around database modernization?
- Absolutely. Absolutely, Sri.
So if a customer is interested in planning
their modernization part with 1CloudHub,

we conduct a free three
day workshop to understand

their business needs and
goals with the migration.
We will run a couple of reports.
Of course, the SCP and the Compass reports

to figure out compatibility
of tooling for their use case.

And then we'll conduct
workshops during the three days

with the application team
to understand or assess

the readiness of the
application for migration.

We'll of course, summarize
all of this into a report

with the business use
case, solution options,
and any possible funding options from AWS
to conduct the migration.

So that's essentially the
way to go to figure out

readiness for the migration
with 1CloudHub, yeah.

- This is very interesting
because now you can decide
before you even start the project,

how complex this migration
is going to look like

simply because you can now
analyze the application

with the help of
Babelfish, Compass reports,

and all the other artifacts
that you are producing.
Correct me if I'm wrong.
- Absolutely, Sri.
This will give us a very good insight

of how much of the
migration will be automatic
using Babelfish or SCP as may be the case.
And also give us areas

where we need to actually
do some manual work,

to get the application
functionality up and running.

So, it gives a good idea of
the cost and the timelines
apart from just the feasibility
or the complexity of migration.
So, definitely important tools to have
before making the decision.

- [Sri] For those who
are watching this video,
you may be wondering where I should start

Microsoft SQL modernization
journey with Babelfish.

The best way to learn Babelfish
is to get your hands dirty
and do a real world app modernization.
To assist with that, we have an amazing
Babelfish app modernization workshop.
You can run it within a few hours

and we will provide you
with an AWS instructor

and free AWS lab accounts
to try the hands-on labs.
During the workshop, you can bring
your existing database schema,

run a Babelfish Compass
assessment to check

the compatibility and the
complexity of your migration.

As Phani said, this is
a great starting point
to assess the risk and put a project plan.

You can also use our database
modernization partners

like 1CloudHub, who can
assist in this journey.
Most of them provide free assessment
to their customers in their engagements.
Once you have a solid project plan,
feel free to reach out to AWS.

And there are some attractive
proof-of-concept funding

available to accelerate
your modernization.

Feel free to check out the
description of this video
for more information.
This is an amazing story, Phani.
I really like your story.
So a customer, let's say,
who wants to be in contact with you
to go through this kind of an assessment,
how can they reach out to you?
- We of course, can go to 1cloudhub.com

or write to us at,
contact us at 1CloudHub,

or call us at any of the
numbers seen on the screen.
- Thanks a lot, Phani, for this session.

I learned a lot from your
explanation around Babelfish

and how these real life
projects are running.

So if any of you are interested
in contacting 1CloudHub
to get your database modernized,

feel free to reach out to them
using this contact number.

Thanks a lot, Phani, for
joining this session,

and in giving your wisdom
around database modernization.
Hope you all enjoyed this session.
Thank you.
- Thank you, Sri.
